title: Cosmetic outcome assessment following breast-conserving therapy: a comparison between BCCT. core software and panel evaluation
author: Haloua, Max Hendrik and Krekel, Nicole Marianna Alexandra and Jacobs, Gerrit Johannes Albertus and Zonderhuis, Barbara and Bouman, Mark-Bram and Buncamper, Marlon Eug{\`e}ne and Niessen, Franciscus Bernardus and Winters, Henri Adolf Hubert and Terwee, Caroline and Meijer, Sybren and others
abstract: Breast-conserving therapy (BCT) is a standard treatment for early breast cancer. Cosmetic outcome is an important endpoint after BCT, and its assessment is often performed by a panel of experts. Recently, the BCCT.core software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of cosmetic results. This study aimed to compare the cosmetic outcome assessment following BCT using the BCCT.core software and a panel evaluation. A total of 51 patients who underwent BCT were included. Standardized photographs were taken and evaluated by a panel of five experts and by the BCCT.core software. The agreement between the two methods was analyzed using weighted kappa statistics. The results showed a moderate agreement between the BCCT.core software and the panel evaluation (weighted kappa = 0.44). The BCCT.core software tended to rate cosmetic outcomes more conservatively compared to the panel. The study concludes that the BCCT.core software provides a reliable and objective assessment of cosmetic outcomes after BCT and can be used as a complementary tool to panel evaluation.

title: kOBCS{\copyright}: a novel software calculator program of the Objective Breast Cosmesis Scale (OBCS)
author: Soror, Tamer and Lancellotta, Valentina and Kov{\'a}cs, Gy{\"o}rgy and Lanzotti, Vito and Tagliaferri, Luca and Cas{\`a}, Calogero and Aristei, Cynthia and Barberini, Francesco and Mahmoud, Mohamed and Badakhshi, Harun
abstract: Objective Breast Cosmesis Scale (OBCS) is a validated tool for the objective assessment of breast cosmesis after breast-conserving surgery. However, the calculation of the OBCS score is complicated and time-consuming. We developed a novel software calculator program, kOBCS©, to facilitate the calculation of the OBCS score. The kOBCS© program was developed using Microsoft Excel and Visual Basic for Applications. The program requires input of the four parameters of the OBCS: breast retraction assessment, nipple deviation, breast contour, and scar appearance. The program automatically calculates the total OBCS score and classifies the cosmetic outcome into excellent, good, fair, or poor. We tested the program using clinical data from 50 patients who underwent breast-conserving surgery. The kOBCS© program significantly reduced the time required for calculation compared to manual calculation (mean time 12.3 vs. 45.7 seconds, p < 0.001). The program showed perfect agreement with manual calculation (intraclass correlation coefficient = 1.0). The kOBCS© program is a user-friendly and reliable tool for the objective assessment of breast cosmesis, which can facilitate clinical and research applications of the OBCS.

title: Plastic surgery: An obstacle for deep face recognition?
author: Rathgeb, Christian and Dogan, Didem and Stockhardt, Fabian and De Marsico, Maria and Busch, Christoph
abstract: Plastic surgery is a challenging problem for face recognition systems. In this paper, we investigate the impact of plastic surgery on deep face recognition. We analyze the performance of state-of-the-art deep face recognition models on a plastic surgery face dataset and compare it with their performance on a standard face dataset. Our experiments show that plastic surgery significantly degrades the performance of deep face recognition systems. We also explore the effectiveness of fine-tuning deep models on plastic surgery data and demonstrate that it can improve recognition accuracy. The findings highlight the need for developing more robust face recognition algorithms that can handle the variations introduced by plastic surgery.

title: An Automatic Framework for Nasal Esthetic Assessment by ResNet Convolutional Neural Network
author: Ashoori, Maryam and Zoroofi, Reza A and Sadeghi, Mohammad
journal: Journal of Imaging Informatics in Medicine
abstract: This study proposes an automatic framework for nasal esthetic assessment using a ResNet convolutional neural network (CNN). The framework aims to provide an objective and efficient evaluation of nasal esthetics by analyzing facial images. By leveraging the deep learning capabilities of ResNet, the model extracts relevant features and predicts esthetic scores that correlate with expert assessments. The proposed method demonstrates high accuracy and robustness, suggesting its potential application in clinical settings for preoperative planning and postoperative evaluation in rhinoplasty procedures.

title: Simulation of Postoperative Facial Appearances via Geometric Deep Learning for Efficient Orthognathic Surgical Planning
author: Ma L.; Xiao D.; Kim D.; Lian C.; Kuang T.; Liu Q.; Deng H.; Yang E.; Liebschner M.A.K.; Gateno J.; Xia J.J.; Yap P.-T.
abstract: Orthognathic surgery corrects jaw deformities to improve aesthetics and functions. Due to the complexity of the craniomaxillofacial (CMF) anatomy, orthognathic surgery requires precise surgical planning, which involves predicting postoperative changes in facial appearance. To this end, most conventional methods involve simulation with biomechanical modeling methods, which are labor intensive and computationally expensive. Here we introduce a learning-based framework to speed up the simulation of postoperative facial appearances. Specifically, we introduce a facial shape change prediction network (FSC-Net) to learn the nonlinear mapping from bony shape changes to facial shape changes. FSC-Net is a point transform network weakly-supervised by paired preoperative and postoperative data without point-wise correspondence. In FSC-Net, a distance-guided shape loss places more emphasis on the jaw region. A local point constraint loss restricts point displacements to preserve the topology and smoothness of the surface mesh after point transformation. Evaluation results indicate that FSC-Net achieves 15× speedup with accuracy comparable to a state-of-the-art (SOTA) finite-element modeling (FEM) method.

title: Preoperative computer simulation in rhinoplasty using previous postoperative images
author: Bashiri-Bawil, Mahdi and Rahavi-Ezabadi, Sara and Sadeghi, Mohammad and Zoroofi, Reza A and Amali, Amin
abstract: Preoperative computer simulation is a useful tool for rhinoplasty; however, it is difficult to create a simulation that reflects the patient’s wishes and the surgeon’s plan. We developed a new simulation method using previous postoperative images of the patient. The simulation was performed using the previous postoperative image as a reference, and the image was morphed to the desired shape. The simulation was performed in 10 patients who underwent primary rhinoplasty. The simulation images were compared with the actual postoperative images, and the accuracy was evaluated. The mean difference between the simulation and the actual postoperative images was 1.2 ± 0.4 mm. The patients and surgeons were satisfied with the simulation images. This method is useful for preoperative simulation in rhinoplasty because it reflects the patient’s wishes and the surgeon’s plan more accurately than conventional methods.

title: 3D-Guided Face Manipulation of 2D Images for the Prediction of Post-Operative Outcome after Cranio-Maxillofacial Surgery
author: Andlauer R.; Wachter A.; Schaufelberger M.; Weichel F.; Kuhle R.; Freudlsperger C.; Nahm W.
abstract: Cranio-maxillofacial surgery often alters the aesthetics of the face which can be a heavy burden for patients to decide whether or not to undergo surgery. Today, physicians can predict the post-operative face using surgery planning tools to support the patient's decision-making. While these planning tools allow a simulation of the post-operative face, the facial texture must usually be captured by another 3D texture scan and subsequently mapped on the simulated face. This approach often results in face predictions that do not appear realistic or lively looking and are therefore ill-suited to guide the patient's decision-making. Instead, we propose a method using a generative adversarial network to modify a facial image according to a 3D soft-tissue estimation of the post-operative face. To circumvent the lack of available data pairs between pre- and post-operative measurements we propose a semi-supervised training strategy using cycle losses that only requires paired open-source data of images and 3D surfaces of the face's shape. After training on 'in-the-wild' images we show that our model can realistically manipulate local regions of a face in a 2D image based on a modified 3D shape. We then test our model on four clinical examples where we predict the post-operative face according to a 3D soft-tissue prediction of surgery outcome, which was simulated by a surgery planning tool. As a result, we aim to demonstrate the potential of our approach to predict realistic post-operative images of faces without the need of paired clinical data, physical models, or 3D texture scans. © 2021 IEEE.

title: Subjective scar assessment scales in orthopaedic surgery and determinants of patient satisfaction: a systematic review of the literature
author: Lastoria, Diego A Abelleyra and Benny, Clerin K and Hing, Caroline B
abstract: Background: Scars are an inevitable consequence of surgery and can have a significant impact on patients' quality of life. Subjective scar assessment scales are commonly used in orthopaedic surgery to evaluate scar appearance and patient satisfaction. This systematic review aims to summarize the available subjective scar assessment scales used in orthopaedic surgery and identify determinants of patient satisfaction with surgical scars.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted in multiple databases to identify studies that utilized subjective scar assessment scales in orthopaedic surgery and reported on factors influencing patient satisfaction. Data on the types of scales used, their psychometric properties, and determinants of satisfaction were extracted and analyzed.  Results: Several subjective scar assessment scales were identified, including the Patient and Observer Scar Assessment Scale (POSAS), Vancouver Scar Scale (VSS), and others. These scales vary in their focus on scar characteristics such as color, texture, and thickness, as well as patient-reported outcomes. Determinants of patient satisfaction included scar visibility, location, symptoms (e.g., pain, itching), and psychological impact. The POSAS was frequently used and demonstrated good reliability and validity.  Conclusions: Subjective scar assessment scales are valuable tools in orthopaedic surgery for evaluating scar outcomes and patient satisfaction. Understanding the determinants of satisfaction can guide surgical techniques and postoperative care to improve patient-centered outcomes. Further research is needed to standardize scar assessment and incorporate patient perspectives in clinical practice.  Keywords: Scar assessment, Orthopaedic surgery, Patient satisfaction, Subjective scales, Systematic review

title: Three-dimensional analysis of nasal symmetry following primary correction of unilateral cleft lip nasal deformity
author: Linden, Olivia E and Taylor, Helena O and Vasudavan, Sivabalan and Byrne, Margaret E and Deutsch, Curtis K and Mulliken, John B and Sullivan, Stephen R
doi: SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA
abstract: Objective: To evaluate nasal symmetry following primary correction of unilateral cleft lip nasal deformity using three-dimensional (3D) imaging. Design: Prospective cohort study. Setting: Tertiary care craniofacial center. Patients: Thirty patients with unilateral cleft lip nasal deformity who underwent primary nasal correction at the time of lip repair. Intervention: Primary nasal correction performed concurrently with cleft lip repair. Main Outcome Measures: 3D nasal surface imaging was performed preoperatively and at 1 year postoperatively. Nasal symmetry was assessed by comparing nasal surface area, nasal projection, and nostril dimensions between the cleft and noncleft sides. Results: At 1 year postoperatively, significant improvement in nasal symmetry was observed. The nasal surface area difference between the cleft and noncleft sides decreased from 15.2% preoperatively to 5.8% postoperatively (p < 0.001). Nasal projection and nostril dimensions also showed significant improvement, with no statistically significant difference between sides at 1 year. Conclusions: Primary nasal correction at the time of unilateral cleft lip repair results in significant improvement in nasal symmetry as objectively measured by 3D imaging. This technique provides a reliable method for assessing surgical outcomes and supports early nasal correction to optimize nasal form in unilateral cleft lip patients.

title: Deep learning for biomechanical modeling of facial tissue deformation in orthognathic surgical planning
author: Lampen, Nathan and Kim, Daeseung and Fang, Xi and Xu, Xuanang and Kuang, Tianshu and Deng, Han and Barber, Joshua and Gateno, Jamie and Xia, James and Yan, Pingkun
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Biomechanical modeling of facial tissue deformation is a key component of computer-assisted orthognathic surgical planning. Finite element (FE) models are the current gold standard but are computationally expensive and require expert knowledge to build. Deep learning (DL) models have the potential to provide fast and accurate predictions of facial tissue deformation. This study aims to develop and evaluate a DL model for biomechanical modeling of facial tissue deformation in orthognathic surgical planning. Methods A DL model based on a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN) was developed to predict facial tissue deformation from bone displacement inputs. The model was trained and tested on a dataset of FE simulations generated from patient-specific anatomical models. The performance of the DL model was evaluated by comparing its predictions with FE simulation results using metrics such as mean surface distance and Dice similarity coefficient. Results The DL model achieved a mean surface distance error of less than 1 mm and a Dice similarity coefficient above 0.9, demonstrating high accuracy in predicting facial tissue deformation. The prediction time was significantly reduced compared to FE simulations, enabling near real-time predictions. Conclusion The proposed DL model provides an accurate and efficient alternative to FE simulations for biomechanical modeling of facial tissue deformation in orthognathic surgical planning. This approach has the potential to improve surgical planning workflows by providing fast and reliable predictions of postoperative facial appearance.

title: A novel computer system for the evaluation of nasolabial morphology, symmetry and aesthetics after cleft lip and palate treatment. Part 1: General concept and validation
author: Pietruski, Piotr and Majak, Marcin and Debski, Tomasz and Antoszewski, Boguslaw
abstract: A novel computer system for the evaluation of nasolabial morphology, symmetry and aesthetics after cleft lip and palate treatment. Part 1: General concept and validation  Abstract: The assessment of nasolabial morphology, symmetry and aesthetics after cleft lip and palate (CLP) treatment is crucial for evaluating surgical outcomes and planning further interventions. Traditional methods rely heavily on subjective clinical judgment, which can lead to variability and inconsistency. This study presents a novel computer system designed to provide objective, reproducible, and quantitative analysis of nasolabial features in patients treated for CLP. The system integrates three-dimensional imaging and advanced morphometric algorithms to assess facial morphology and symmetry comprehensively. Validation was performed using a cohort of CLP patients and control subjects, demonstrating high accuracy and reliability compared to expert clinical evaluations. This approach offers a promising tool for standardized assessment in both clinical practice and research, facilitating improved treatment planning and outcome monitoring in CLP care.

title: Correspondence attention for facial appearance simulation
author: Xi Fang and Daeseung Kim and Xuanang Xu and Tianshu Kuang and Nathan Lampen and Jungwook Lee and Hannah H. Deng and Michael A.K. Liebschner and James J. Xia and Jaime Gateno and Pingkun Yan
abstract: Facial appearance simulation is a fundamental task in computer vision and graphics, aiming to generate realistic and controllable facial images. Traditional methods often struggle to capture fine-grained details and complex correspondences between facial regions. In this paper, we propose a novel correspondence attention mechanism that effectively models the spatial relationships and appearance variations across facial features. Our approach leverages attention to establish dense correspondences, enabling high-fidelity facial appearance synthesis with improved detail preservation and expression transfer. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms existing techniques in both qualitative and quantitative evaluations, offering a powerful tool for applications such as facial reenactment, animation, and virtual avatar creation.

title: Nerf: Representing scenes as neural radiance fields for view synthesis
author: Mildenhall, Ben and Srinivasan, Pratul P and Tancik, Matthew and Barron, Jonathan T and Ramamoorthi, Ravi and Ng, Ren
abstract: We present a method that represents complex 3D scenes as continuous 5D neural radiance fields, which are functions that output volume density and view-dependent emitted radiance at any spatial location and viewing direction. Our approach, called Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF), optimizes a fully connected deep network to represent the scene by minimizing the error between the rendered views and the input images. This representation enables photorealistic novel view synthesis of complex scenes with intricate geometry and view-dependent effects, outperforming prior state-of-the-art methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of NeRF on challenging real-world scenes and synthetic datasets, showing its ability to synthesize novel views with high fidelity and fine detail.

title: GOMPS: global attention-based ophthalmic image measurement and postoperative appearance prediction system
author: Huang, Xingru and Li, Zhi and Lou, Lixia and Dan, Ruilong and Chen, Lingxiao and Zeng, Guodong and Jia, Gangyong and Chen, Xiaodiao and Jin, Qun and Ye, Juan and others
abstract: With the rapid development of ophthalmic surgery, the demand for accurate ophthalmic image measurement and postoperative appearance prediction has increased significantly. In this paper, we propose GOMPS, a global attention-based ophthalmic image measurement and postoperative appearance prediction system. GOMPS integrates a global attention mechanism to effectively capture the spatial dependencies in ophthalmic images, enhancing the accuracy of measurement and prediction tasks. The system employs a novel deep learning framework that combines convolutional neural networks with global attention modules to analyze preoperative images and predict postoperative outcomes. Experimental results on multiple ophthalmic datasets demonstrate that GOMPS outperforms existing methods in both measurement precision and appearance prediction accuracy, providing a valuable tool for clinicians in surgical planning and patient consultation.

title: Regularized ordinal regression and the ordinalNet R package
author: Wurm, Michael J and Rathouz, Paul J and Hanlon, Bret M
abstract: Regularized regression methods such as the lasso and elastic net have become popular tools for high-dimensional data analysis. While these methods are well developed for continuous and binary outcomes, there has been less work on regularized regression for ordinal outcomes. We present a coordinate descent algorithm for fitting a family of ordinal regression models with elastic net penalties, including the proportional odds model, the nonparallel cumulative logit model, and the continuation ratio model. We implement this algorithm in the R package ordinalNet, which provides functions for fitting these models, selecting tuning parameters by cross-validation, and making predictions. We illustrate the use of ordinalNet with examples and simulations, demonstrating its utility for high-dimensional ordinal regression problems.

title: Development of a new patient-reported outcome measure for breast surgery: the BREAST-Q
author: Pusic, Andrea L and Klassen, Anne F and Scott, Amie M and Klok, Jennifer A and Cordeiro, Peter G and Cano, Stefan J
abstract: BACKGROUND: Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) are essential for evaluating the effectiveness of breast surgery from the patient's perspective. The BREAST-Q is a new PROM developed to assess outcomes in breast surgery patients, including satisfaction with breasts, psychosocial, sexual, and physical well-being, and satisfaction with care. METHODS: The BREAST-Q was developed using qualitative interviews with patients, expert input, and rigorous psychometric methods. The instrument was field-tested with a large sample of breast surgery patients, and psychometric analyses were conducted to evaluate reliability, validity, and responsiveness. RESULTS: The BREAST-Q demonstrated excellent internal consistency, test-retest reliability, and construct validity. It was sensitive to clinical changes and able to discriminate between different patient groups. CONCLUSIONS: The BREAST-Q is a reliable and valid PROM that can be used to assess patient outcomes in breast surgery, facilitating patient-centered care and comparative effectiveness research.

title: DeltaFace: fully automatic 3D facial cosmetic surgery simulation
author: Chanchua, Adawat and Chentanez, Nuttapong
abstract: This paper presents DeltaFace, a fully automatic 3D facial cosmetic surgery simulation system. DeltaFace is designed to assist surgeons and patients in visualizing the potential outcomes of cosmetic facial surgeries. The system integrates advanced 3D face reconstruction techniques with a novel deformation model that simulates surgical modifications realistically. By leveraging deep learning and geometric modeling, DeltaFace can generate personalized and accurate 3D facial models from a single input image and simulate various cosmetic procedures automatically. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of DeltaFace in producing high-quality simulations that can enhance preoperative planning and patient communication.

title: Usefulness of mirror image processing software for creating images of expected appearance after blepharoptosis surgery
author: Mawatari, Yuki and Kawaji, Takahiro and Kakizaki, Hirohiko and Vaidya, Aric and Takahashi, Yasuhiro
abstract: Purpose To evaluate the usefulness of mirror image processing software for creating images of expected appearance after blepharoptosis surgery. Methods This retrospective study included 35 patients who underwent blepharoptosis surgery. Preoperative photographs were processed using mirror image software to create images simulating the expected postoperative appearance by mirroring the contralateral eyelid. The simulated images were compared with actual postoperative photographs taken 3 months after surgery. The degree of agreement between simulated and actual postoperative images was assessed using subjective evaluation by patients and surgeons and objective measurements of eyelid parameters. Results The simulated images closely resembled the actual postoperative appearance in most cases. Both patients and surgeons reported high satisfaction with the accuracy of the simulated images. Objective measurements showed no significant differences between simulated and actual postoperative eyelid parameters. Conclusions Mirror image processing software is useful for creating images that simulate the expected postoperative appearance after blepharoptosis surgery. This tool can aid in preoperative counseling and help manage patient expectations.

title: Breast asymmetry, classification, and algorithm of treatment: our experience
author: de Vita, Roy and Buccheri, Ernesto Maria and Villanucci, Amedeo and Ragusa, Luigi Amerigo
abstract: Breast asymmetry is a common condition that can cause significant psychological distress and affect quality of life. The aim of this study is to propose a classification system and an algorithm for the treatment of breast asymmetry based on our clinical experience. We retrospectively reviewed patients treated for breast asymmetry at our institution, analyzing the types and degrees of asymmetry, associated deformities, and surgical outcomes. Our classification divides breast asymmetry into four main types according to volume, shape, and position discrepancies. The treatment algorithm considers patient age, breast development, and specific asymmetry characteristics to guide surgical planning. The proposed classification and algorithm facilitate a systematic approach to diagnosis and management, improving aesthetic results and patient satisfaction. This study underscores the importance of individualized treatment strategies in breast asymmetry correction.

title: Cosmetic evaluation of breast conserving treatment for mammary cancer. 1. Proposal of a quantitative scoring system
author: Van Limbergen, Erik and Van der Schueren, E and Van Tongelen, K
abstract: A quantitative scoring system for the cosmetic evaluation of breast conserving treatment for mammary cancer is proposed. The system is based on the assessment of four parameters: breast size, shape, nipple position and scar appearance. Each parameter is scored on a scale from 0 to 3, with higher scores indicating better cosmetic results. The total score ranges from 0 to 12, allowing for an objective and reproducible evaluation of cosmetic outcome after breast conserving therapy. This scoring system facilitates comparison between different treatment modalities and can be used in clinical trials to assess the impact of various therapeutic approaches on breast cosmesis.

title: Unsupervised generative model for simulating post-operative double eyelid image
author: Wu R.; Liao S.; Dai P.; Han F.; Kui X.; Song X.
journal: Physical and Engineering Sciences in Medicine
abstract: Simulating the outcome of double eyelid surgery is a challenging task. Many existing approaches rely on complex and time-consuming 3D digital models to reconstruct facial features for simulating facial plastic surgery outcomes. Some recent research performed a simple affine transformation approach based on 2D images to simulate double eyelid surgery outcomes. However, these methods have faced challenges, such as generating unnatural simulation outcomes and requiring manual removal of masks from images. To address these issues, we have pioneered the use of an unsupervised generative model to generate post-operative double eyelid images. Firstly, we created a dataset involving pre- and post-operative 2D images of double eyelid surgery. Secondly, we proposed a novel attention-class activation map module, which was embedded in a generative adversarial model to facilitate translating a single eyelid image to a double eyelid image. This innovative module enables the generator to selectively focus on the eyelid region that differentiates between the source and target domain, while enhancing the discriminator’s ability to discern differences between real and generated images. Finally, we have adjusted the adversarial consistency loss to guide the generator in preserving essential features from the source image and eliminating any masks when generating the double eyelid image. Experimental results have demonstrated the superiority of our approach over existing state-of-the-art techniques. © Australasian College of Physical Scientists and Engineers in Medicine 2024.

title: An artificial intelligence-based cosmesis evaluation for temporomandibular joint reconstruction
author: Hidaka, Takeaki and Tanaka, Kentaro and Mori, Hiroki
abstract: Background: Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) reconstruction is a complex surgical procedure that can significantly impact facial cosmesis. Traditional methods for evaluating postoperative cosmesis are subjective and lack standardization. This study aims to develop and validate an artificial intelligence (AI)-based system for objective cosmesis evaluation following TMJ reconstruction.  Methods: A dataset of postoperative facial images from patients who underwent TMJ reconstruction was collected. An AI model utilizing deep learning techniques was trained to assess facial symmetry and aesthetic outcomes. The model's performance was compared with evaluations by expert clinicians using standardized cosmesis scoring systems.  Results: The AI-based system demonstrated high accuracy in detecting asymmetries and predicting cosmesis scores, with strong correlation to expert assessments (Pearson's r = 0.87, p < 0.001). The model provided consistent and reproducible evaluations, reducing interobserver variability.  Conclusion: The AI-based cosmesis evaluation system offers an objective, reliable, and efficient tool for assessing facial aesthetics after TMJ reconstruction. This technology has the potential to enhance postoperative assessment, guide surgical planning, and improve patient outcomes.  Level of Evidence: 4.

title: Statistical model based 3D shape prediction of postoperative trunks for non-invasive scoliosis surgery planning
author: K.C. Assi and H. Labelle and F. Cheriet
abstract: Accurate prediction of the postoperative trunk shape is essential for non-invasive scoliosis surgery planning. This paper presents a statistical model-based approach to predict the 3D shape of the postoperative trunk from preoperative data. The method involves constructing a statistical shape model of the trunk from a training set of 3D reconstructions, capturing the variability of trunk shapes in scoliotic patients. Using this model, the postoperative trunk shape is predicted by estimating the shape parameters that best fit the expected surgical correction. The approach is validated on a dataset of patients with pre- and postoperative 3D trunk reconstructions, demonstrating its ability to accurately predict postoperative trunk shapes. This method provides a non-invasive tool for surgical planning, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient care in scoliosis treatment.

title: Towards an intelligent medical system for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer conservative treatment
author: Cardoso, Jaime S and Cardoso, Maria J
abstract: Breast cancer conservative treatment (BCCT) is a surgical technique that combines tumor removal with radiotherapy. The aesthetic evaluation of the results of BCCT is a complex task that requires the analysis of several clinical and photographic parameters. This paper presents an intelligent medical system designed to assist clinicians in the aesthetic evaluation of BCCT outcomes. The system integrates image processing techniques with artificial intelligence methods to analyze clinical photographs and extract relevant features. These features are then used to classify the aesthetic results into predefined categories. The proposed system aims to provide an objective, reproducible, and efficient tool to support clinical decision-making and improve patient care in breast cancer treatment.

title: A narrative review of artificial intelligence (AI) for objective assessment of aesthetic endpoints in plastic surgery
author: Atiyeh, Bishara and Emsieh, Saif and Hakim, Christopher and Chalhoub, Rawad
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has rapidly evolved and is increasingly being integrated into various medical specialties, including plastic surgery. Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes remains a significant challenge due to the subjective nature of beauty and the variability in human judgment. This narrative review aims to explore the current applications of AI in the objective evaluation of aesthetic endpoints in plastic surgery. We discuss the types of AI technologies employed, such as machine learning and deep learning algorithms, and their roles in analyzing pre- and postoperative images to quantify surgical outcomes. The review highlights the potential benefits of AI, including improved accuracy, consistency, and efficiency in aesthetic assessments, as well as the challenges and limitations faced, such as data quality, ethical considerations, and the need for standardized protocols. Future directions for research and clinical implementation are also proposed to enhance the integration of AI in plastic surgery practice, ultimately aiming to improve patient satisfaction and surgical results.

title: The effect of cosmetic surgery on self-esteem and body image: a systematic review and meta-analysis of clinical trial studies
author: Kazeminia, Mohsen and Salari, Nader and Heydari, Mohammadbagher and Akbari, Hakimeh and Mohammadi, Masoud
abstract: Purpose This study aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effect of cosmetic surgery on self-esteem and body image based on clinical trial studies. Methods A systematic search was conducted in PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, and Google Scholar databases from inception to July 2021. Clinical trial studies that evaluated the effect of cosmetic surgery on self-esteem and body image were included. The quality of the included studies was assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias tool. A random-effects meta-analysis was performed to estimate the pooled effect size. Results Ten clinical trial studies with a total of 512 participants were included. The meta-analysis showed a significant improvement in self-esteem (standardized mean difference [SMD] = 0.78; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.45 to 1.11; p < 0.001) and body image (SMD = 0.85; 95% CI: 0.52 to 1.18; p < 0.001) after cosmetic surgery. Subgroup analyses indicated that the effect was consistent across different types of cosmetic surgery and follow-up durations. Conclusion Cosmetic surgery has a positive effect on self-esteem and body image based on clinical trial evidence. These findings support the psychological benefits of cosmetic surgery, but further high-quality trials with longer follow-up are needed to confirm these results.

title: A novel approach to keypoint detection for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer surgery outcomes
author: Gon{\c{c}}alves, Tiago and Silva, Wilson and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: Breast cancer surgery is a common treatment for breast cancer patients, and the aesthetic outcome of the surgery is an important factor affecting patients’ quality of life. Traditional methods for evaluating the aesthetic outcome rely on subjective assessments by clinicians, which can be inconsistent and time-consuming. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to keypoint detection for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer surgery outcomes. Our method utilizes deep learning techniques to automatically detect keypoints on breast images, enabling objective and reproducible measurements of surgical results. We validate our approach on a dataset of postoperative breast images and demonstrate its effectiveness in capturing relevant aesthetic features. The proposed method has the potential to assist clinicians in providing standardized and quantitative assessments of breast surgery outcomes, ultimately improving patient care.

title: Application of generative adversarial networks (GAN) for ophthalmology image domains: a survey
author: You, Aram and Kim, Jin Kuk and Ryu, Ik Hee and Yoo, Tae Keun
abstract: Generative adversarial networks (GANs) have recently emerged as a powerful deep learning framework for image generation and transformation. In ophthalmology, GANs have been increasingly applied to various image domains, including fundus photography, optical coherence tomography (OCT), and fluorescein angiography, to address challenges such as data scarcity, image enhancement, and disease diagnosis. This survey provides a comprehensive review of the state-of-the-art applications of GANs in ophthalmic imaging. We categorize the existing literature based on the specific ophthalmic image modalities and the tasks performed, such as image synthesis, segmentation, classification, and anomaly detection. Furthermore, we discuss the advantages and limitations of GAN-based methods in ophthalmology, highlight the challenges faced in clinical translation, and suggest potential future research directions to advance the integration of GANs into ophthalmic practice. This survey aims to serve as a valuable resource for researchers and clinicians interested in leveraging GANs for ophthalmic image analysis and to foster further innovation in this rapidly evolving field.

title: Digital images in academic plastic surgery: a novel and secure methodology for use in clinical practice and research
author: Hallac, Rami R and Dumas, Blaike M and Seaward, James R and Herrera, Royiel and Menzies, Christopher and Kane, Alex A
doi: SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA
abstract: Background: Digital images are essential in plastic surgery for documentation, education, and research. However, concerns about patient confidentiality and data security limit their use. This study presents a novel, secure methodology for capturing, storing, and sharing digital images in academic plastic surgery settings.  Methods: We developed a secure digital imaging protocol integrating encrypted storage, controlled access, and standardized metadata tagging. The system was implemented in a plastic surgery department, and its usability, security, and compliance with institutional and legal standards were evaluated over 12 months.  Results: The protocol enabled efficient image capture and retrieval while maintaining patient confidentiality. User feedback indicated high satisfaction with the system's ease of use and security features. No breaches of data security were reported during the study period.  Conclusions: The proposed methodology offers a practical and secure approach to managing digital images in academic plastic surgery. It facilitates clinical practice and research while ensuring compliance with confidentiality requirements, potentially serving as a model for other surgical specialties.

title: Machine learning and surgical outcomes prediction: a systematic review
author: Elfanagely, Omar and Toyoda, Yoshiko and Othman, Sammy and Mellia, Joseph A and Basta, Marten and Liu, Tony and Kording, Konrad and Ungar, Lyle and Fischer, John P
abstract: Background: Machine learning (ML) is a subset of artificial intelligence that uses algorithms to identify patterns in data and make predictions. ML has been increasingly applied in surgery to predict outcomes and improve patient care. This systematic review aims to evaluate the current evidence on the use of ML for surgical outcomes prediction.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted in multiple databases to identify studies that applied ML techniques to predict surgical outcomes. Studies were screened, and data were extracted on ML methods, surgical specialties, outcomes predicted, and performance metrics.  Results: A total of 45 studies met inclusion criteria, encompassing various surgical specialties including general surgery, orthopedics, and neurosurgery. ML models demonstrated promising predictive performance for outcomes such as postoperative complications, mortality, and length of stay. Commonly used algorithms included random forests, support vector machines, and neural networks. However, heterogeneity in study design, outcome definitions, and ML methodologies was noted.  Conclusions: ML shows potential in predicting surgical outcomes and aiding clinical decision-making. Nevertheless, further research with standardized methodologies and external validation is necessary to translate these models into clinical practice effectively. title: PlasticGAN: Holistic generative adversarial network on face plastic and aesthetic surgery
author: Chandaliya, Praveen Kumar and Nain, Neeta
abstract: Plastic surgery is a surgical specialty involving the restoration, reconstruction, or alteration of the human body. In recent years, the number of plastic surgery cases has increased rapidly, and the demand for plastic surgery has also increased. However, the lack of professional plastic surgery doctors and the high cost of plastic surgery have limited the development of plastic surgery. To solve these problems, this paper proposes a holistic generative adversarial network (PlasticGAN) for face plastic and aesthetic surgery. PlasticGAN can generate realistic face images after plastic surgery, which can help doctors and patients to better understand the effect of plastic surgery. Specifically, PlasticGAN consists of a generator and a discriminator. The generator is designed to generate face images after plastic surgery, and the discriminator is designed to distinguish between real and generated images. Moreover, PlasticGAN introduces a holistic loss function to ensure the generated images are both realistic and consistent with the input images. Experimental results on a face plastic surgery dataset demonstrate that PlasticGAN can generate high-quality face images after plastic surgery, which can be used for plastic surgery simulation and aesthetic evaluation.

title: Generative adversarial nets
author: Goodfellow, Ian J and Pouget-Abadie, Jean and Mirza, Mehdi and Xu, Bing and Warde-Farley, David and Ozair, Sherjil and Courville, Aaron and Bengio, Yoshua
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems
abstract: We propose a new framework for estimating generative models via an adversarial process, in which we simultaneously train two models: a generative model G that captures the data distribution, and a discriminative model D that estimates the probability that a sample came from the training data rather than G. The training procedure for G is to maximize the probability of D making a mistake. This framework corresponds to a minimax two-player game. In the space of arbitrary functions G and D, a unique solution exists, with G recovering the training data distribution and D equal to 1/2 everywhere. In the case where G and D are defined by multilayer perceptrons, the entire system can be trained with backpropagation. There is no need for any Markov chains or unrolled approximate inference networks during either training or generation of samples. Experiments demonstrate the potential of the framework through qualitative and quantitative evaluation of the generated samples.

title: Computer simulation tool for rhinoplasty planning
author: Ozkul, Tarik and Ozkul, Murat Haluk
abstract: Computer simulation tools are becoming increasingly important in the planning of surgical procedures. In rhinoplasty, the ability to predict postoperative nasal shape is crucial for both surgeons and patients. This paper presents a computer simulation tool designed to assist in rhinoplasty planning by providing a three-dimensional visualization of the nasal anatomy and allowing for virtual modifications. The tool integrates patient-specific data obtained from medical imaging and employs biomechanical modeling to simulate tissue behavior. Results demonstrate that the simulation can effectively predict postoperative outcomes, enhancing surgical planning and patient communication. The system's user-friendly interface facilitates its adoption in clinical practice, potentially improving surgical precision and patient satisfaction.

title: Image quality assessment: from error visibility to structural similarity
author: Wang, Zhou and Bovik, Alan C and Sheikh, Hamid R and Simoncelli, Eero P
abstract: Image quality assessment (IQA) is a fundamental problem in image processing. Traditional methods, such as mean squared error (MSE) and peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), have been widely used but often fail to correlate well with perceived visual quality. In this paper, we propose a new approach to IQA based on the concept of structural similarity (SSIM). The SSIM index is designed to improve upon traditional methods by incorporating important perceptual phenomena, including luminance masking and contrast masking. The method compares local patterns of pixel intensities that have been normalized for luminance and contrast, thus capturing structural information in the image. Experimental results demonstrate that the SSIM index is highly consistent with human visual perception and outperforms existing methods in predicting image quality. This approach provides a promising direction for developing more effective IQA metrics that align closely with human visual system characteristics.

title: Pre-operative drawings of anticipated closures as a visual tool to align patient and physician expectations for Mohs and reconstructive surgery
author: Trager, Megan H and Queen, Dawn and Denson, Elizabeth and Fan, Weijia and Youssef, Soundos and Samie, Faramarz H
abstract: Pre-operative drawings of anticipated closures as a visual tool to align patient and physician expectations for Mohs and reconstructive surgery  Abstract: Patient expectations are a critical component of surgical satisfaction and outcomes. In Mohs micrographic surgery and subsequent reconstruction, aligning patient and physician expectations can be challenging due to the complexity of defect closures. This study evaluates the use of pre-operative drawings depicting anticipated closures as a visual tool to improve communication and expectation alignment between patients and physicians. We conducted a prospective analysis involving patients undergoing Mohs surgery with planned reconstruction. Pre-operative drawings illustrating the anticipated closure were presented and discussed with patients prior to surgery. Patient understanding, satisfaction, and alignment of expectations were assessed through surveys and interviews. Results demonstrated that the use of pre-operative drawings significantly enhanced patient comprehension of the surgical plan, improved satisfaction with outcomes, and reduced discrepancies between patient and physician expectations. Incorporating visual aids such as pre-operative drawings into the surgical consultation process is a valuable strategy to optimize patient-centered care in Mohs and reconstructive surgery. title: Predictive images of postoperative levator resection outcome using image processing software
author: Mawatari, Yuki and Fukushima, Mikiko
abstract: Purpose: To evaluate the usefulness of image processing software in predicting the postoperative appearance of the eyelid after levator resection for blepharoptosis. Patients and methods: This study included 16 patients (19 eyelids) who underwent levator resection for blepharoptosis. Preoperative photographs were processed using image processing software to simulate the postoperative eyelid appearance. The predicted images were compared with the actual postoperative photographs taken 3 months after surgery. The margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) was measured in both predicted and actual postoperative images. Results: The predicted images closely resembled the actual postoperative appearance in terms of eyelid contour and MRD1. The mean difference between predicted and actual MRD1 was minimal and not statistically significant. Conclusion: Image processing software can be a useful tool for predicting postoperative eyelid appearance after levator resection, aiding in surgical planning and patient counseling.

title: Role of artificial intelligence and machine learning in facial aesthetic surgery: A systematic review
author: Stephanian, Brooke and Karki, Sabin and Debnath, Kirin and Saltychev, Mikhail and Rossi-Meyer, Monica and Kandathil, Cherian Kurian and Most, Sam P
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) in facial aesthetic surgery has the potential to revolutionize patient outcomes, surgical planning, and postoperative care. This systematic review aims to evaluate the current applications, benefits, and limitations of AI and ML technologies in facial aesthetic procedures. A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies focusing on AI and ML in facial aesthetic surgery. The findings highlight advancements in preoperative imaging analysis, predictive modeling for surgical outcomes, automated facial feature recognition, and personalized treatment planning. Despite promising results, challenges such as data privacy, algorithmic bias, and the need for large, diverse datasets remain. The review underscores the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration to harness AI and ML effectively, ensuring ethical implementation and improved patient care in facial aesthetic surgery.

title: Subjective assessment of facial aesthetics after maxillofacial orthognathic surgery for obstructive sleep apnoea
author: Islam, Shofiq and Aleem, Fahd and Ormiston, Ian W
journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
abstract: Introduction: Maxillomandibular advancement (MMA) surgery is an effective treatment for obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA). However, the aesthetic outcome of this surgery is not well documented. This study aimed to assess subjective facial aesthetic changes following MMA surgery for OSA.  Materials and methods: A prospective study was conducted on patients undergoing MMA surgery for OSA. Pre- and postoperative standardized photographs were taken. Subjective facial aesthetics were assessed by patients, surgeons, and laypeople using a visual analogue scale (VAS). Changes in facial aesthetics were compared pre- and postoperatively.  Results: Twenty patients were included. Postoperative assessments showed a significant improvement in facial aesthetics scores by patients, surgeons, and laypeople (p < 0.05). The majority of patients reported satisfaction with their postoperative facial appearance. Surgeons and laypeople also rated postoperative facial aesthetics more favorably.  Conclusion: MMA surgery for OSA results in subjective improvement in facial aesthetics as perceived by patients, surgeons, and laypeople. These findings support the dual benefit of MMA surgery in treating OSA and enhancing facial appearance.

title: Evaluation of reconstructed auricles by convolutional neural networks
author: Ye, Jiong and Lei, Chen and Wei, Zhenni and Wang, Yuqi and Zheng, Houbing and Wang, Meishui and Wang, Biao
journal: Journal of Plastic, Reconstructive \& Aesthetic Surgery
abstract: Background: Reconstruction of the auricle is a challenging procedure in plastic surgery. Evaluation of the reconstructed auricle is important for both clinical and research purposes. This study aimed to develop a convolutional neural network (CNN) model to evaluate reconstructed auricles automatically.  Methods: A total of 500 images of reconstructed auricles and normal auricles were collected. The images were labeled by experienced plastic surgeons. A CNN model was trained to classify the images into reconstructed or normal auricles. The performance of the model was evaluated using accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC).  Results: The CNN model achieved an accuracy of 92%, sensitivity of 90%, specificity of 94%, and an AUC of 0.96 in distinguishing reconstructed auricles from normal auricles. The model demonstrated robust performance across different reconstruction techniques and image qualities.  Conclusions: The CNN model provides an effective and objective method for evaluating reconstructed auricles. This approach has potential applications in clinical assessment and outcome research in auricular reconstruction.

title: Image-to-image translation with conditional adversarial networks
author: Isola, Phillip and Zhu, Jun-Yan and Zhou, Tinghui and Efros, Alexei A
abstract: Image-to-image translation is a class of vision and graphics problems where the goal is to learn the mapping between an input image and an output image using a training set of aligned image pairs. Recent work has shown that this mapping can be learned with convolutional networks trained with a pixel-wise loss, but these approaches often result in blurry outputs. We propose a general-purpose solution to image-to-image translation problems using conditional adversarial networks, which learn a loss function to train the mapping. Our approach not only learns the mapping from input to output images but also learns a loss function to train this mapping. We demonstrate that this approach is effective for a wide variety of problems, including synthesizing photos from label maps, reconstructing objects from edge maps, and colorizing images, among others. Our method produces sharper results than prior methods and can be trained end-to-end with a single network.

title: Real time 3D simulation for nose surgery and automatic individual prosthesis design
author: Wang J.-X.; Liao S.-H.; Zhu X.-H.; Wang Y.; Ling C.-X.; Ding X.; Fang Y.-M.; Zhang X.-H.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: This paper presents an intuitive nose surgery planning and simulation system, using 3D laser scan image and lateral X-ray image, to provide high quality prediction of the postoperative appearance, and design the patient specific prosthesis model automatically. After initial registration, the internal surface of soft tissue at the nose region was generated by the statistical data for soft tissue thickness adapted by the individual thickness information from the X-ray image. Then, the sketch contour of the 3D scan data on the lateral X-ray image was modified manually or adjusted automatically according to some aesthetic statistical data, to drive the simulation in real time by the state-of-the-art Laplacian surface deformation method. When satisfied with the 3D postoperative appearance, the deformation was mapped to the internal surface of soft tissue, and the change before and after simulation was utilized to generate the patient specific prosthesis model automatically. The surgeons who used the system confirmed that this planning system is attractive and has potential for daily clinical practice. © 2010 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.

title: The use of a breast symmetry index for objective evaluation of breast cosmesis
author: Fitzal, F and Krois, W and Trischler, H and Wutzel, L and Riedl, O and K{\"u}hbelb{\"o}ck, U and Wintersteiner, B and Cardoso, Maria J and Dubsky, P and Gnant, M and others
abstract: Breast cosmesis is an important outcome measure following breast conserving surgery (BCS). However, there is no widely accepted objective method of assessing breast cosmesis. We have developed a breast symmetry index (BSI) based on the measurement of breast volume and nipple position from standardised digital photographs. The BSI was tested in 30 patients who had undergone BCS and radiotherapy. The BSI was compared with subjective assessments of breast cosmesis by a panel of three clinicians and the patients themselves. The BSI correlated well with the subjective assessments (clinician panel: r = 0.75, p < 0.001; patient assessment: r = 0.68, p < 0.001). The BSI provides an objective, reproducible and non-invasive method of assessing breast cosmesis following BCS. It may be useful in clinical trials and in routine clinical practice.

title: Deep keypoint detection for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer surgery outcomes
author: Silva, Wilson and Castro, Eduardo and Cardoso, Maria J and Fitzal, Florian and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: Breast cancer surgery aims to remove the tumor while preserving the breast’s appearance. The aesthetic outcome is an important factor for patients’ quality of life and satisfaction. However, the evaluation of aesthetic outcomes is subjective and time-consuming. In this paper, we propose a deep learning-based method for automatic keypoint detection on breast images to facilitate the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer surgery outcomes. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network to detect anatomical landmarks, which are then used to compute aesthetic scores. Experimental results on a dataset of postoperative breast images demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in accurately detecting keypoints and its potential to assist in objective aesthetic assessment.

title: Attention is all you need
author: Vaswani, Ashish and Shazeer, Noam and Parmar, Niki and Uszkoreit, Jakob and Jones, Llion and Gomez, Aidan N and Kaiser, {\L}ukasz and Polosukhin, Illia
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems
abstract: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature.

title: Differentiable simulation for outcome-driven orthognathic surgery planning
author: Dorda, Daniel and Peter, Daniel and Borer, Dominik and Huber, Niko Benjamin and Sailer, Irena and Gross, Markus and Solenthaler, Barbara and Thomaszewski, Bernhard
abstract: Orthognathic surgery planning requires accurate prediction of postoperative facial appearance to achieve desired aesthetic and functional outcomes. Traditional simulation methods often rely on manual adjustments and lack differentiability, limiting their integration with optimization algorithms for outcome-driven planning. In this paper, we propose a differentiable simulation framework for orthognathic surgery planning that enables gradient-based optimization of surgical parameters to directly achieve target postoperative outcomes. Our approach models the biomechanical behavior of facial soft tissues and skeletal structures using differentiable components, allowing efficient computation of gradients with respect to surgical manipulations. We validate our method on clinical cases, demonstrating improved accuracy in predicting postoperative facial appearance and enhanced capability for automated, outcome-driven surgical planning. This work paves the way for more precise and personalized orthognathic surgery interventions through differentiable simulation techniques.

title: A fully automatic framework for evaluating cosmetic results of breast conserving therapy
author: Guo, Chenqi and Smith, Tamara L and Feng, Qianli and Benitez-Quiroz, Fabian and Vicini, Frank and Arthur, Douglas and White, Julia and Martinez, Aleix
abstract: Breast conserving therapy (BCT) is a common treatment for early-stage breast cancer, aiming to remove the tumor while preserving breast appearance. Evaluating cosmetic outcomes post-BCT is crucial for patient quality of life and treatment assessment. This paper presents a fully automatic framework for evaluating cosmetic results of BCT using machine learning and image analysis techniques. The proposed method integrates breast segmentation, feature extraction, and classification to assess cosmetic outcomes objectively. Experimental results on a dataset of post-BCT breast images demonstrate the effectiveness and reliability of the framework, showing potential for clinical application in routine cosmetic evaluation.

title: SC-FEGAN: Face editing generative adversarial network with user's sketch and color
author: Jo, Youngjoo and Park, Jongyoul
abstract: We present SC-FEGAN, a novel face editing system that allows users to edit face images using free-form masks, sketches, and color inputs. Unlike previous face editing methods that require precise masks or are limited to specific attributes, our approach enables intuitive and flexible editing by combining user sketches and color strokes with a generative adversarial network (GAN). The network is trained to generate high-quality, realistic face images that conform to the user's input while preserving the original image's identity and background. We demonstrate that SC-FEGAN outperforms existing methods in terms of visual quality and user control, making it a practical tool for interactive face image editing.

title: How to produce complementary explanations using an ensemble model
author: Silva, Wilson and Fernandes, Kelwin and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to produce complementary explanations using an ensemble model. Unlike traditional methods that generate a single explanation, our approach leverages the diversity of an ensemble of models to provide multiple, complementary explanations for a given prediction. We introduce a framework that combines the outputs of individual models in the ensemble to highlight different aspects of the input data that contribute to the final decision. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method produces explanations that are more informative and comprehensive compared to existing single-model explanation techniques. This work opens new avenues for enhancing the interpretability of complex machine learning models by exploiting ensemble diversity.

title: CleftLipGAN: Interactive GAN-Inpainting for Post-Operative Cleft Lip Reconstruction
author: Atputharuban, Daniel Anojan and Theopold, Christoph and Lawlor, Aonghus
abstract: Cleft lip is a common congenital deformity that affects the upper lip and nose, often requiring multiple surgical interventions for functional and aesthetic restoration. Post-operative assessment and planning for secondary surgeries are critical for optimal outcomes but remain challenging due to the complex anatomy and variability in healing. In this paper, we propose CleftLipGAN, an interactive generative adversarial network (GAN) based inpainting framework designed to assist surgeons in visualizing potential post-operative outcomes for cleft lip reconstruction. Our method enables intuitive editing and realistic synthesis of lip and nasal regions, facilitating better pre-surgical planning and patient communication. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CleftLipGAN on a dataset of cleft lip images, showing its capability to generate plausible reconstructions that respect anatomical structures and surgical constraints. This approach represents a novel application of GANs in craniofacial surgery, offering a valuable tool for enhancing surgical planning and education.

title: R 2-resnext: A resnext-based regression model with relative ranking for facial beauty prediction
author: Lin, Luojun and Liang, Lingyu and Jin, Lianwen
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) is a challenging task due to the subjective nature of beauty and the lack of large-scale labeled datasets. In this paper, we propose a novel regression model named R 2-ResNeXt, which is based on the ResNeXt architecture and incorporates a relative ranking loss to improve the prediction accuracy of facial attractiveness scores. The relative ranking loss helps the model to learn the relative order of facial beauty scores, which is more consistent with human perception. We evaluate our model on the SCUT-FBP5500 dataset and demonstrate that R 2-ResNeXt outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean absolute error and correlation coefficients. Our approach provides a promising direction for FBP by combining deep residual networks with ranking-based learning.

title: Applied deep learning in plastic surgery: classifying rhinoplasty with a mobile app
author: Borsting, Emily and DeSimone, Robert and Ascha, Mustafa and Ascha, Mona
abstract: Background: Rhinoplasty is one of the most common cosmetic surgical procedures performed worldwide. However, the assessment of nasal deformities and surgical planning remains challenging and subjective. This study aimed to develop and evaluate a mobile application using deep learning to classify rhinoplasty types based on preoperative photographs.  Methods: A convolutional neural network (CNN) was trained on a dataset of 1,200 preoperative nasal photographs labeled according to rhinoplasty classification. The model was integrated into a mobile app for real-time classification. The app's performance was evaluated on a separate test set of 300 images and compared with assessments by experienced plastic surgeons.  Results: The CNN achieved an accuracy of 87% in classifying rhinoplasty types on the test set. The mobile app demonstrated high usability and provided instant classification results. The model's performance was comparable to that of expert surgeons, with a Cohen's kappa coefficient of 0.82 indicating substantial agreement.  Conclusions: The developed mobile app utilizing deep learning shows promise as a tool for assisting plastic surgeons in the objective classification of rhinoplasty types. This technology may enhance preoperative planning and patient communication, potentially improving surgical outcomes. Further studies with larger datasets and diverse populations are warranted to validate and refine the model.

title: Applications of machine learning in facial cosmetic surgeries: a scoping review
author: Ahmadi, Nima and Niazmand, Maral and Ghasemi, Ali and Mohaghegh, Sadra and Motamedian, Saeed Reza
abstract: Background: Machine learning (ML) has been increasingly applied in various medical fields, including facial cosmetic surgeries, to enhance diagnostic accuracy, surgical planning, and outcome prediction. This scoping review aims to systematically map the existing literature on the applications of ML in facial cosmetic surgeries, identify current trends, and highlight potential areas for future research.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies employing ML techniques in facial cosmetic surgery contexts. Studies were screened and selected based on predefined inclusion criteria. Data were extracted regarding the types of ML algorithms used, surgical applications, outcomes measured, and study designs.  Results: The review included studies focusing on preoperative assessment, surgical simulation, postoperative outcome prediction, and complication risk stratification using ML models. Commonly used algorithms included convolutional neural networks, support vector machines, and random forests. Applications ranged from facial feature analysis and aesthetic outcome evaluation to personalized surgical planning. Despite promising results, challenges such as limited datasets, lack of standardization, and ethical considerations were noted.  Conclusions: ML holds significant potential to revolutionize facial cosmetic surgeries by improving precision and personalized care. However, further research with larger, diverse datasets and standardized methodologies is necessary to validate and integrate ML tools into clinical practice effectively.  Keywords: machine learning, facial cosmetic surgery, artificial intelligence, surgical planning, outcome prediction, scoping review

title: Prediction of facial soft tissue deformations with improved Rubin-Bodner model after craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery
author: Zhang, Guangming and Xia, James J and Zhang, Xiaoyan and Zhou, Xiaobo
abstract: Accurate prediction of facial soft tissue deformations after craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery is important for surgical planning and outcome evaluation. In this paper, an improved Rubin-Bodner model is proposed to predict facial soft tissue deformations after CMF surgery. The improved model incorporates a nonlinear elasticity term and a spatially varying stiffness parameter to better capture the complex biomechanical behavior of facial soft tissues. The model parameters are estimated using preoperative and postoperative 3D facial scans of patients. Experimental results demonstrate that the improved Rubin-Bodner model achieves higher accuracy in predicting postoperative facial soft tissue deformations compared to the original model, showing its potential for clinical applications in CMF surgery planning.

title: 3D Gaussian Splatting for Real-Time Radiance Field Rendering
author: Kerbl, Bernhard and Kopanas, Georgios and Leimk{\"u}hler, Thomas and Drettakis, George
abstract: We present 3D Gaussian Splatting, a novel representation and rendering approach for radiance fields that enables real-time novel view synthesis. Unlike prior work that represents scenes as a continuous volumetric function, we represent a scene as a set of 3D Gaussians, each with a spatial location, covariance, and view-dependent color. This representation allows us to directly render the scene by splatting the Gaussians onto the image plane, leveraging efficient rasterization hardware. Our approach achieves high-quality rendering results with detailed geometry and view-dependent effects, while being orders of magnitude faster than previous methods. We demonstrate real-time rendering of complex scenes with high fidelity, enabling interactive applications and new possibilities for radiance field rendering.

title: Densely connected convolutional networks
author: Huang, Gao and Liu, Zhuang and Van Der Maaten, Laurens and Weinberger, Kilian Q
abstract: We introduce DenseNet, a new architecture that connects each layer to every other layer in a feed-forward fashion. For each layer, the feature-maps of all preceding layers are used as inputs, and its own feature-maps are used as inputs into all subsequent layers. DenseNet alleviates the vanishing-gradient problem, strengthens feature propagation, encourages feature reuse, and substantially reduces the number of parameters. DenseNets have been shown to achieve state-of-the-art results on several image classification benchmarks, including CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, SVHN, and ImageNet. Our experiments demonstrate that DenseNets require fewer parameters and less computation to achieve comparable or better accuracy than traditional convolutional networks.

title: Reliability of the BCCT. core software in evaluation of breast cosmesis--A systematic review
author: Trakis, Stami and Lord, Heidi and Graham, Peter and Fernandez, Ritin
journal: Journal of Medical Imaging and Radiation Oncology
abstract: Abstract Background: The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software is a tool designed to objectively evaluate breast cosmesis after breast-conserving therapy. This systematic review aims to assess the reliability of the BCCT.core software in evaluating breast cosmesis.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies that evaluated the reliability of the BCCT.core software. Studies were included if they assessed the software's reproducibility, validity, or agreement with other assessment methods.  Results: The review included several studies demonstrating that the BCCT.core software has good intra- and interobserver reliability. The software showed substantial agreement with expert panel assessments and other objective measures. However, some variability was noted depending on image quality and assessment protocols.  Conclusion: The BCCT.core software is a reliable tool for the objective evaluation of breast cosmesis following breast-conserving therapy. Its use can standardize cosmetic assessments and support clinical decision-making and research in breast cancer treatment outcomes. Further studies are recommended to optimize imaging protocols and validate the software across diverse populations. title: Use of convolutional neural networks to evaluate auricular reconstruction outcomes for microtia
author: Tolba, Mariam and Qian, Z Jason and Lin, Hung-Fu and Yeom, Kristen W and Truong, Mai Thy
abstract: Background: Auricular reconstruction for microtia is a challenging procedure, and evaluation of surgical outcomes is important for quality control and improvement. This study aimed to develop a convolutional neural network (CNN) model to evaluate auricular reconstruction outcomes objectively.  Methods: A total of 500 postoperative auricular images from microtia patients were collected and labeled by experienced surgeons as "satisfactory" or "unsatisfactory." The dataset was divided into training, validation, and test sets. A CNN model was trained to classify the images based on surgical outcomes. Model performance was evaluated using accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC).  Results: The CNN model achieved an accuracy of 87.2%, sensitivity of 85.5%, specificity of 88.9%, and an AUC of 0.92 on the test set. The model's predictions showed strong agreement with expert evaluations, demonstrating its potential as an objective tool for outcome assessment.  Conclusion: The CNN-based model provides an effective and objective method for evaluating auricular reconstruction outcomes in microtia patients. This approach may assist surgeons in postoperative assessment and contribute to improving surgical quality.

title: f-AnoGAN: Fast unsupervised anomaly detection with generative adversarial networks
author: Schlegl, Thomas and Seeb{\"o}ck, Philipp and Waldstein, Sebastian M and Langs, Georg and Schmidt-Erfurth, Ursula
abstract: Anomaly detection in medical imaging is a challenging task due to the scarcity of abnormal samples and the high variability of normal anatomy. In this work, we propose f-AnoGAN, a fast and unsupervised anomaly detection method based on generative adversarial networks (GANs). Our approach improves upon the AnoGAN framework by introducing an encoder network that maps images directly to the latent space of the GAN, enabling rapid anomaly scoring without the need for iterative optimization. We evaluate f-AnoGAN on brain MRI datasets for the detection of multiple sclerosis lesions and brain tumors, demonstrating superior performance and significantly reduced inference time compared to previous methods. Our results suggest that f-AnoGAN is a promising tool for efficient and accurate unsupervised anomaly detection in medical imaging.

title: Orbital and maxillofacial computer aided surgery: Patient-specific finite element models to predict surgical outcomes
author: Luboz V.; Chabanas M.; Swider P.; Payan Y.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This paper addresses an important issue raised for the clinical relevance of Computer-Assisted Surgical applications, namely the methodology used to automatically build patient-specific finite element (FE) models of anatomical structures. From this perspective, a method is proposed, based on a technique called the mesh-matching method, followed by a process that corrects mesh irregularities. The meshmatching algorithm generates patient-specific volume meshes from an existing generic model. The mesh regularization process is based on the Jacobian matrix transform related to the FE reference element and the current element. This method for generating patient-specific FE models is first applied to computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery, and more precisely, to the FE elastic modelling of patient facial soft tissues. For each patient, the planned bone osteotomies (mandible, maxilla, chin) are used as boundary conditions to deform the FE face model, in order to predict the aesthetic outcome of the surgery. Seven FE patientspecific models were successfully generated by our method. For one patient, the prediction of the FE model is qualitatively compared with the patient's post-operative appearance, measured from a computer tomography scan. Then, our methodology is applied to computer-assisted orbital surgery. It is, therefore, evaluated for the generation of 11 patient-specific FE poroelastic models of the orbital soft tissues. These models are used to predict the consequences of the surgical decompression of the orbit. More precisely, an average law is extrapolated from the simulations carried out for each patient model. This law links the size of the osteotomy (i.e. the surgical gesture) and the backward displacement of the eyeball (the consequence of the surgical gesture). © 2005 Taylor & Francis Ltd.

title: Simulation of the postoperative trunk appearance in scoliosis surgery
author: Dionne, Olivier and Assi, Kondo Claude and Grenier, S{\'e}bastien and Labelle, Hubert and Guibault, Fran{\c{c}}ois and Cheriet, Farida
abstract: Scoliosis surgery aims to correct the spinal deformity and improve the trunk appearance. However, the postoperative trunk appearance is difficult to predict due to the complex three-dimensional (3D) changes of the spine and the soft tissue deformation. In this paper, we propose a method to simulate the postoperative trunk appearance based on the preoperative 3D spine model and the planned surgical correction. The spine correction is simulated by applying the surgical parameters to the preoperative spine model, and the soft tissue deformation is estimated using a biomechanical model. The simulated postoperative trunk surface is then generated and visualized. Experimental results on clinical data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in predicting the postoperative trunk appearance, which can assist surgeons in surgical planning and patient communication.

title: Multiscale modeling and distributed computing to predict cosmesis outcome after a lumpectomy
author: Garbey, Marc and Salmon, Remi and Thanoon, David and Bass, Barbara L
abstract: Breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) is a common treatment for breast cancer. However, the cosmetic outcome after surgery is highly variable and difficult to predict. We present a multiscale computational model that integrates tissue mechanics, wound healing, and breast anatomy to predict postoperative breast shape and cosmesis. The model incorporates patient-specific imaging data and simulates the biomechanical response of breast tissue to surgical resection and subsequent healing processes. To handle the computational complexity, we employ distributed computing techniques that enable efficient simulation of the multiscale model. Our results demonstrate that the model can predict postoperative breast deformation and cosmetic outcomes with reasonable accuracy, providing a potential tool for surgical planning and patient counseling.
